#Text=Taiwan-China flights begin
#Text=Saturday , January 29 , 2005
#Text=BEIJING/TAIPEI — Nonstop flights between mainland China and Taiwan took off Saturday for the first time in more than half a century .
#Text=Traditional dragon dancers in bright costumes performed on the tarmac as three airplanes prepared to leave Beijing 's airport Saturday , the first to fly nonstop to Taiwan since 1949 .
#Text=The ceremony marked the first of 48 charter flights allowed to operate between Taiwan and the mainland over the three-week Chinese New Year holiday season .
#Text=Later , a China Southern Airlines plane , which took off from the Guangzhou , landed at Taipei 's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport amid similar fanfare .
#Text=This marked the first successful direct flight across the two sides , still technically at war .
#Text=The Republic of China government banned direct flights after the Kuomintang defeat in the Chinese Civil War to the Communists caused the government to retreat to Taiwan .

#Text=Although there is consensus on all sides to resume the three links — direct postal , telephone , and airline links — between mainland China and Taiwan , Taiwan 's President Chen Shui-bian has been reluctant to move ahead , citing the possibility that the People 's Republic of China could disguise troop carriers as commercial airliners to invade Taiwan .
#Text=All normal airline flights between the two sides have to be routed through a third party — usually Hong Kong — making a three hour flight between Taipei and Shanghai last eight hours .
#Text=Taiwanese and mainland airlines are forbidden to travel into their respective airspaces , forcing passengers to change airlines too .
#Text=These restrictions were first lifted for Chinese New Years in 2003 , but those flights still stopped briefly in Hong Kong .
#Text=Taiwanese legislator John Chang , the grandson of former President Chiang Kai-shek , spoke of the flights ' significance at the ceremony .
#Text=Mr. Chang said that despite differences , the flights symbolize " the hopes of the two sides for peace , stability , dialogue and mutual development . "

column1: #Text=Mr. Chang had been part of the group of opposition lawmakers that helped arrange the flights .
#Text=This year 's flights were planned after diplomatic negotiations in Macau , ending on January 15 .
#Text=They are aimed to allow the easy reuniting of families which are split between the island and the mainland for the celebrations .
#Text=The ROC government hopes the flights can form the basis for further negotiations and better relations with the People 's Republic of China .
#Text=However , the PRC , which is refusing to deal with the independence -leaning government of President Chen , is less optimistic .
#Text=Most of the passengers taking advantage of the nonstop flights , running until February 20 , are Taiwanese businesspeople who work on the mainland .
#Text=Many Taiwanese have lobbied their government to ease its ban on direct air links , especially as trade continues to grow between the island and the mainland , despite the political tensions .
#Text=Mainland Chinese officials this month said cross-strait trade had reached a record $ 70 billion in 2004 .
